metadata.title: Malaria vaccine based on Self-Assembling Protein Nanoparticles

abstract.original_text: Despite recent progress with GSK's RTS'S malaria vaccine, there remains a desperate need for an efficient malaria vaccine. We have used a repetitive antigen display technology to display malaria specific B cell and T cell epitopes in an effort to design a vaccine against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Our protein sequence when assembled into a nanoparticle induces strong, long-lived and protective immune responses against infection with the parasite. We are confident that the clinical trials with our most developed vaccine candidate will show good protection in a controlled human malaria infection trial.

sentences.segment_text: Despite recent progress with GSK 's RTS 'S malaria vaccine ,
there remains a desperate need for an efficient malaria vaccine .
We have used a repetitive antigen display technology to display malaria specific B cell and T cell epitopes in an effort to design a vaccine against Plasmodium falciparum malaria .
Our protein sequence when assembled into a nanoparticle induces strong ,
long-lived and protective immune responses against infection with the parasite .
We are confident that the clinical trials with our most developed vaccine candidate will show good protection in a controlled human malaria infection trial .
